abstract.p: Assemblyman Richard N Gottfried letter, comment on Aug 25 article, urges New York City to enforce construction codes rather than letting building owners and developers 'self-certify' that they comply with law

block.p: The brick that fell from the apartment tower construction site atop the West Side Y.M.C.A. is the latest in a series of construction and demolition accidents in New York City (''Woman Suffers Minor Injuries When Brick Falls at 63rd Street Apartment Construction Site,'' news article, Aug. 25). These include disasters and near-disasters involving building collapses, falling cranes and falling debris.

The brick that fell from the apartment tower construction site atop the West Side Y.M.C.A. is the latest in a series of construction and demolition accidents in New York City (''Woman Suffers Minor Injuries When Brick Falls at 63rd Street Apartment Construction Site,'' news article, Aug. 25). These include disasters and near-disasters involving building collapses, falling cranes and falling debris.
But accidents don't just happen; they are caused.

New York City has undermined code enforcement by letting building owners and developers ''self-certify'' that they are complying with the law. The mayor and the City Council need to hire more code enforcement personnel to enforce construction codes.
RICHARD N. GOTTFRIED Member of Assembly, 64th Dist. New York, Aug. 25, 2000
